questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false about the rhythm method?

options.a: Anencephaly is seen on accidental conception
options.b: It is a cost effective method
options.c: Safe period is determined using temperature or mucous method
options.d: Abstinence is required for 7-10 days in a month

questions.explanation:
Anencephaly is not seen in the case of accidental conception in a woman using the rhythm 
method. It occurs due to deficiency of folic acid in the mother. The calendar method or the rhythm method is one of the natural methods of contraception by 
fertility awareness. The couple is advised avoidance of sexual intercourse around ovulation. Thus, 
it is very cost-effective but it can only be used by educated couples. According to this method, safe period in a normal 28-day cycle is from the 1st day of menstrual 
period to the 10th day and from the 18th to the 28th day. An alternate method is by calculating 
the risk period i.e., 3 days before and 3 days after ovulation. Ovulation can also be estimated by 
changes in cervical mucus and basal body temperature. Another method of calculating the safe period is the Knaus–Ogino method. The fertile period is 
determined by subtracting 18 days from the shortest cycle and 10 days from the longest cycle. 
This gives the first and the last day of the fertile period, respectively.

questions.question: Question 2: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
questions.explanation:
Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation 
method. The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can 
predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus. Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and 
elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of 
progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days. Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes 
the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day. The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below. 679 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image. 670 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 
cm in length with a flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the 
outer ring. The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers 
the cervix, the entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and 
STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male 
condom. It can be fitted by the patient hours before intercourse, and easily removed soon after. It covers 
the cervix, vagina, and external genitalia and is protective against sexually transmitted diseases. It 
can also be worn in the puerperal period, unlike the cervical diaphragm. The female condom should not be used along with a male condom because if worn together they 
may slip, tear, or become displaced. The given image below shows the insertion of a female condom:

questions.question:
Question 4: A nulliparous woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this 
contain?
questions.explanation:
Today sponge contains 1 g of nonoxynol 9. It is a mushroom-shaped polyurethane 
disposable sponge that is 2 inches wide and 1.25 inches thick. It is provided with a loop for easy removal. It should be placed high up in the vagina with the 
concave side covering the cervix. It can remain effective for 24 h. It can be used only once. It acts as a mechanical barrier preventing the entry of sperms into the cervical canal, absorbs 
semen, and contains a spermicidal agent. The failure rate is 9-16 per 100 woman-years. 680 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the use of the contraceptive shown 
below?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a cervical diaphragm or Dutch cap. It can be used by women having 
multiple sex partners. Contraindications of cervical diaphragm usage: • Prolapse, cystocele, rectocele - accurate fitting is not possible • Recurrent urinary tract infection • Allergy to rubber or spermicidal agent It must be removed following intercourse as it can lead to toxic shock syndrome (TSS) if left in the 
vagina for a long period. TSS is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus 
aureus infection.

questions.question:
Question 6: You are prescribing nonoxynol-9 jelly to a woman using a cervical diaphragm for 
contraception. What is its mechanism of action?
questions.explanation:
Nonoxynol-9 is one of the spermicidal agents which act by disruption of the sperm cell 
membrane. Spermicidal agents are chemical contraceptives as they contain surfactants, such as nonoxynol-9, 
octoxynol, menfegol and enzyme-inhibiting agents. These are available as: • Foam tablets • Soluble pessaries • Creams • Jellies • Films 681 
Sold by @itachibot The spermicidal agent remains effective for 1–2 hours after the application. They are always used 
along with other contraceptives such as the diaphragm, cervical cap, and condom. When they are 
used alone, the failure rate is high i.e., 30 per 100 woman-years. Chronic use of spermicides can cause vaginal irritation, abrasion, and ulceration. This increases 
the risk of HIV spread. Hence, spermicidal agents should not be recommended to HIV-positive 
couples.

questions.question:
Question 7: A young woman who is using a cervical diaphragm asks for an alternative contraceptive. You 
suggest a recently launched contraceptive Phexxi. What is its composition?

options.a: Lactic acid, Citric Acid, Potassium bitartrate
options.b: Ascorbic acid, Citric acid, Calcium bitartrate
options.c: Lactic acid, Ascorbic acid, Potassium bitartrate
options.d: Ascorbic acid, Lactic acid, Calcium bitartrate.

questions.explanation:
Phexxi is a vaginal gel that contains lactic acid, citric acid, and potassium bitartrate. Phexxi is a vaginal pH regulator which is a non-hormonal contraceptive. It works by maintaining 
vaginal pH within the range of 3.5 to 4.5. This acidic environment is inhospitable for sperms. Phexxi comes in pre-filled vaginal applicators. A single dose must be applied before vaginal 
intercourse. If more than one act of vaginal intercourse occurs within one hour, an additional dose 
must be applied.

questions.question: Question 8: A newly married woman was prescribed Mala-N at a PHC. What is its composition?
questions.explanation:
Mala-N is a combined oral contraceptive containing 0.15 mg levonorgestrel (LNG) and 0.03 
mg ethinyl estradiol. It is supplied free of cost through all PHC's, urban family welfare centers, 
etc. All combined oral pills contain a mixture of ethinyl estradiol in a dose of 20-30 mcg and an orally 
active progestogen. Mala-D has the same composition as Mala-N but is available at a price of Rs 
3/- per packet. Combined oral pill works by suppressing pituitary hormones, FSH, and LH peak which prevents 
ovulation. At the same time, progestogen causes atrophic changes in the endometrium and 682 
Sold by @itachibot prevents implantation. Progestogen also acts on the cervical mucus making it thick and tenacious and impenetrable by 
sperms. It also interferes with tubal motility and alters tubal transport. , so the fertilized egg reaches the uterine cavity before the endometrium is receptive for 
implantation. These tablets are taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. A new course of tablets 
should be commenced 7 days after the cessation of the previous course. They should be taken at 
bedtime, preferably after a meal.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not an advantage of norgestimate OCPs?
questions.explanation:
Norgestimate is one of the 3rd generation progesterone agents. All OCPs have the disadvantage 
of increasing the risk of venous thrombosis. Third-generation progesterone agents are less androgenic and so reduce the occurrence of acne 
and hirsutism. They also have a lower risk of metabolic and cardiovascular disorders compared to 
the previous generation progesterone agents. Benefits of combined pills: • Effective contraceptive • Useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhoea • Relieves dysmenorrhoea and premenstrual tension • Prevents anaemia by reducing the menstrual loss • Lower incidence of benign breast neoplasia (fibrocystic disease), functional ovarian cyst, ovarian 
and uterine malignancy • Reduced risk of PID - due to thick cervical mucus caused by progestogen, preventing the 
organisms from entering into the uterine cavity • Reduced incidence of ectopic pregnancy - due to suppression of ovulation and decreased risk of 
PID • Protects against rheumatoid arthritis • Reduces the risk of anorectal cancer • Useful in acne, PCOD, and endometriosis

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of OCPs?
questions.explanation:
Thyroid disorders like hypothyroidism are not a contraindication for OCP usage. Contraindications of OCPs: • Absolute contraindications - • Breast and genital cancers 683 
Sold by @itachibot • Liver disease • History of thromboembolism • Cardiac abnormalities • Congenital hyperlipidemia • Undiagnosed abnormal uterine bleeding • Relative contraindications - • Age over 40 years, if smoker >35 years • Mild hypertension • Chronic renal disease • Epilepsy • Migraine • First 6 months of breastfeeding • Diabetes mellitus • Gallbladder disease • History of infrequent bleeding or amenorrhea

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following drugs do not lead to failure of OCPs?
questions.explanation:
Sodium valproate is an inhibitor of CYP enzymes that are responsible for OCP metabolism. Thus, 
it does not lead to OCP failure. Drugs leading to OCP failure are : • Rifampicin • Tetracyclines - interferes with enterohepatic circulation of estrogen • Phenytoin • Phenobarbitone • Antifungals • Cephalosporin • Ritonavir for HIV - interferes with absorption of OCP Most of the anti-convulsants are enzyme inducers and hence increase the clearance of OCPs. This 
leads to OCP failure.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?

options.c: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.explanation:
Minipills or progesterone-only pills (POP) do not kill sperm in the cervical canal. 
Progesterone-only pills act by thickening the cervical mucus (the main mechanism of all POPs 684 
Sold by @itachibot except cerazette) that inhibits penetration of sperms, inhibiting tubal motility, and suppressing 
ovulation. Other advantages of POPs include a reduction in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory diseases 
and sexually transmitted diseases (due to thickened cervical mucus). Due to the inhibition of tubal motility, the absolute risk of all pregnancies including ectopic 
pregnancy decreases, while the relative risk of ectopic pregnancy increases. But a previous history 
of ectopic pregnancy is not a contraindication for POP. POPs do not affect clotting, lipid metabolism, and carbohydrate metabolism. So they can safely be 
used by women who are obese, breastfeeding, hypertensive, have SLE or a history of 
thromboembolism, diabetic with vascular disease. Significant adverse effects of POPs are irregular 
bleeding (mostly scanty), and secondary amenorrhea after longtime usage as it causes endometrial 
atrophy. Contraindications for POPs include undiagnosed vaginal bleeding, pregnancy, known or suspected 
breast cancer, and benign or malignant liver tumors.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient has come to your clinic for contraceptive advice. As she has a family history of 
breast cancer, you suggest a non-hormonal oral contraceptive to her. What is the initial dose 
of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Centchroman is a non-hormonal oral contraceptive that is started at a dose of 30 mg on the first 
day of the menstrual cycle. It can be given to women with a family history of breast cancer where 
hormonal contraceptives are contraindicated. Centchroman or ormeloxifene is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive. Following the initial dose 
of 30 mg on the first day of menses, it is taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter. It 
prevents implantation through endometrial changes. The return of fertility occurs within 6 
months of stopping the drug. It can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in 60 mg dose within 24 hours of coitus. It has a 
failure rate of 1.83 per 100 woman years. It does not provide protection against HIV and other 
STDs. Side effects of centchroman: • Headache, nausea, vomiting • Weight gain • Delay in return of fertility (up to 6 months) • Atypical endometrial hyperplasia - prolonged use Contraindications of centchroman: • PCOD • Hepatic dysfunction • Cervical dysplasia • Allergy to the drug This drug has been developed by Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow. It has been released 
in India under the name of Chhaya (previously called Saheli) under the National Family Planning 685 
Sold by @itachibot Programme.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is the most effective reversible method of contraception?
questions.explanation:
The most effective reversible method of contraception among the given options is Norplant, which 
is a subdermal hormonal implant. The most effective method of contraception overall is sterilization, which is one of the permament 
methods. Both methods belong to the first-tier category of contraceptives. There are 2 types of subdermal implants: • Implanon (which has replaced Norplant I) • Norplant II The implants work by inhibition of ovulation, endometrial atrophy, and thickening of cervical 
mucus. Implanon contains desogestrel and also reduces acne and osteoporosis. The implants are inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 
weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 
days of insertion. The image below shows an implanon: 686 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows the insertion of a subdermal implant: Advantages of implants: • Long-acting with sustained effect • Good compliance • Coital-independent with no nuisance of daily oral or frequent injections • Failure rate - 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman-years • Implanon reduces acne and osteoporosis. Disadvantages of implants: • Breakthrough bleeding • Irregular cycles 687 
Sold by @itachibot • Amenorrhoea • Ectopic pregnancy • Local infection • Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules • Expensive.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper containing IUCDs. Formation 
of cervical mucus plug is not one of its mechanisms of action. However, progesterone-containing 
IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects. The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are: • Interference with the migration of spermatozoa • Foreign body reaction releasing prostaglandins - provokes uterine contractility and increases the 
tubal peristalsis which interferes with implantation • Leucocytic infiltration in the endometrium - macrophages engulf the fertilized egg if it enters the 
endometrial tissue • Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue which interferes with implantation 
of the fertilized ovum Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years. They are a good choice of method of contraception for the following groups of women: • Having low risk of STD • Multiparous woman • Having a monogamous relationship • Wanting long-term reversible method of contraception • Unreliable users of oral contraception or barrier contraception IUCDs are avoided in unmarried and nulliparous patients because of the risk of PID and 
subsequent tubal infertility. Copper IUCDs can also be used as emergency contraception following 
intercourse.

questions.question:
Question 16: 674 
Sold by @itachibot IUCD insertion is being considered in a multiparous woman who wants long-term 
contraception. This method of contraception is absolutely contraindicated in all of the 
following except  
.
questions.explanation:
IUCDs can be used in HIV-affected women. Intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCDs) provide long-term contraception by preventing 
fertilization. Contraindications for IUCD insertion: 688 
Sold by @itachibot • Suspected pregnancy • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) • Lower genital tract infection • Presence of fibroids • Severe anaemia • Uncontrolled diabetes - due to increased pelvic infection • Scarred uterus eg, post caesarean section • Septate uterus • Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea - if Copper T is used • Breast cancer - if LNG IUCD is used Complications of IUCD usage: • Immediate - • Vasovagal attack • Uterine cramps • Early - • Expulsion of IUCD • Perforation of uterus • Spotting, menorrhagia • Dysmenorrhoea • Vaginal infection • Actinomycosis • Late - • PID • Ectopic pregnancy • Perforation of uterus • Menorrhagia • Dysmenorrhoea The failure rate of IUCD is 1–3 per 100 woman-years. Levonorgestrel IUCD also causes hormonal adverse effects such as headache, acne, breast 
tenderness, and functional ovarian cysts. Amenorrhoea occurs in 35% of women after 2 years of 
use.

questions.question:
Question 17: You are inserting Nova-T in a patient for spacing of births. This device contains 
.
questions.explanation:
689 
Sold by @itachibot Nova-T contains both copper and silver. The addition of the silver increases its effective lifespan. In copper-carrying devices, copper wire is wrapped around the vertical stem of a polypropylene 
frame. Some of them have copper wire wrapped around the arms too. Based on the surface area, 
they are of various types: • Copper T 380 A • Multiload copper 250 • Copper T 200 • Copper 7 • Copper T 220 • Nova-T They are effective for 3–5 years. It is estimated that about 50 mcg of copper is eluted daily in the 
uterus. Copper T 380A, known as Paraguard, has a lifespan of 10 years. Nova T has a lifespan of 5 
years. 690 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A nursing mother was prescribed progestasert for contraception. How much progesterone is 
released by this device?
questions.explanation:
Progestasert releases 65 g of progesterone/day. Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in a silicon oil reservoir in the 
vertical stem. The progesterone released causes the formation of a thick plug of mucus at the 
cervical os. This prevents entry of the sperms in addition to the local contraceptive effect of 
IUCDs. There is lesser incidence of menstrual problems like menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea compared 
to copper-containing intrauterine devices. However, it is expensive and requires yearly 
replacement.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following increases the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease?
questions.explanation:
Copper IUCDs increase the risk of PID. OCPs, Mirena and DMPA injectables contain progesterone which causes thickening of the cervical 
mucus and decreases the motility of the female genital tract. Thus, they reduce the risk of PID by 
preventing the ascent of bacteria from the vagina.

questions.question: Question 20: What is the most effective mode of contraception for a woman with heart disease?
questions.explanation:
IUCDs are the most effective mode of contraception for women with heart diseases. IUCDs are 
safe in these patients and come under the first-tier contraceptive methods. Condoms are not contraindicated in heart disease patients but they are third-tier contraceptives. 
Hence, they are not as effective as IUCDs. 691 
Sold by @itachibot OCPs and hormonal implants are contraindicated in patients with heart diseases as the 
constituent hormones can cause thromboembolic disorders.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following techniques of permanent contraception does not require an abdominal 
incision?
questions.explanation:
Essure permanent device is a method of hysteroscopic sterilization. Pomeroy, Parkland, and 
Irving procedures are methods for tubal ligation via an abdominal approach. Essure device consists of a micro-inserter with a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a 
dynamic outer coil made of nickel titanium alloy (nitinol). This device is inserted into the fallopian tube by hysteroscopy. It acts by benign local fibrous 
tissue growth leading to occlusion of the tube. The failure rate is 3.5%. Its advantages are that there is no abdominal scar and the procedure can be done under local 
anaesthesia. Disadvantages of Essure: • Hysteroscopy required for the procedure and to confirm the blockage • Expensive procedure • Expertise required • Irreversible - tuboplasty for reversal not possible • 3 months waiting time to ensure sterility - HSG must be done after 3 months to confirm tubal 
blockage • Bilateral insertion difficult due to spasm • Can cause perforation of the tube 692 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: A woman has come to your clinic for a checkup following tubal ligation by Pomeroy 
technique. Which portion of the tube is ligated in this technique?
questions.explanation:
Isthmus of the fallopian tube is ligated in Pomeroy technique. It is the most popular technique of 
tubal ligation. Midline, paramedian or transverse abdominal incision is made 2 inches above the pubic 
symphysis (1 inch in puerperal sterilisation). The fallopian tube is identified, made into a loop and 
tied at the base. The loop is then excised. The operation is simple and requires a short period of hospitalization. The failure rate is only 
0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization. It is surgically reversible. The below image shows Pomeroy’s method of tubal ligation.

questions.question: Question 23: Fimbriectomy is also known as:
questions.explanation:
Fimbriectomy is also known as Kroener's procedure. This procedure involves ligation of the distal 
ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures. Then, resection of the infundibulum of the tube 
is done. 693 
Sold by @itachibot Some more techniques of permanent sterilization include: Pomeroy method - The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. 
The middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. This is 
the most commonly used technique. Uchida's method - The tubal serosa is stripped off the muscular layer in the midsegment of the 
tube. The muscle layer is excised. The proximal end is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. 
This minimal excision of the tube preserves the potential for tuboplasty. 694 
Sold by @itachibot Irving's procedure - The mid-portion of the tube is ligated and the intervening portion is excised. 
The proximal end is buried in the myometrium and the distal end is buried in the broad ligament. 
It is a reliable method but irreversible and may require a laparotomy incision. Madlener's procedure - A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a 
nonabsorbable suture. 695 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A 40-year-old male patient underwent a vasectomy. What is the failure rate of this 
procedure?
questions.explanation:
The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15% This procedure is done under local anaesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas 
deferens are divided on both sides which disrupts the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps 
and skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The sperms can remain in the reproductive tract for up to 3 months. Hence, sterility is not 
immediate. The couple must abstain from intercourse during this period or use other methods of 
contraception. Approximately, 20 ejaculates clear the semen of all sperms. Two semen analysis reports must 
confirm the absence of sperms before the man can be declared sterile. 696 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 25: A couple with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse requires emergency contraception. 
Which of the following is not a mechanism by which these drugs act?

options.c: Preventing the implantation of the fertilized egg

questions.explanation:
Emergency contraceptives do not interrupt early pregnancy, once conception has occured. They 
are used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. Hence, they are also 
called interceptives. The main action of emergency contraceptives is to make the endometrium unsuitable for 
implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation, and prevent fertilization of the egg by 
sperms. Methods of emergency contraception: Drug 
Dose Levonorgestrel 
0.75mg stat and repeat dose 
after 12 hours or1.5mg as a si 
ngle dose Ethinyl estradiol 50 g + Nor 
gestrel 0.25 mg 2 tabs stat and 2 tabs after 12 hours RU486 (Mifepristone) 
Single dose of 25-50mg Ethinyl Estradiol 
2.5 mg BD X 5 days Copper IUDs 
Insertion within 5 days of int 
ercourse Centchroman 
2 tabs(60 mg) to be taken twi 
ce at an interval of 12 hoursS 
hould be taken within 24 hou 
rs of intercourse. Ulipristal 
30 mg within 5 days of interc 
ourse

questions.question:
Question 26: A 23-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of unprotected intercourse 2 days ago. 
Which of the following will you prescribe as a single dose contraceptive?
questions.explanation:
Levonorgestrel (LNG) 1.5 mg i.e. 2 tablets of LNG 0.75 mg can be used as a single dose emergency 
contraceptive. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. Alternatively, one tablet of LNG 0.75mg can be followed by another tablet 12 hours later. The 
tablets can be offered up to 120 hours but the efficacy decreases with the increase in interval 
between coitus and drug intake. LNG prevents ovulation and makes endometrium unsuitable for implantation. The failure rate is 
1.1%. If pregnancy occurs as a result of contraceptive failure, the risk of ectopic pregnancy 
increases but it is not teratogenic. Advantages of LNG: • No oestrogen and its associated side effects 697 
Sold by @itachibot • Can be used in hypertensive, cardiac and diabetic patients • Suitable for lactating woman • Can be given up to 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse • Single-dose therapy Contraindications of LNG: • Liver disease • Thrombophlebitis • Migraine • Galactose allergy - as the tablet contains lactose

questions.question: Question 27: What is the dose of ulipristal for emergency contraception?
questions.explanation:
The dose of ulipristal is 30 mg tablet and it should be taken within 5 days of intercourse. Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor 
and acts by: • Preventing/delaying ovulation • Suppressing endometrial and follicular growth • Inhibiting implantation Side effects are headaches and mood changes. It is contraindicated in women with severe hepatic 
dysfunction and severe asthma. Note: The use of ulipristal for the treatment of fibroids has been discontinued due to the increased 
incidence of severe liver injury. 698 
Sold by @itachibot Vaginal Infections
